CAUTION: this only works on people who can read well enough to do this. which is fewer and fewer people, as recording devices become more and more readily available. Advantage of notation, is that you can read while you are playing, where as you can't really play something from a recording in real-time. Do you plan the visuals in your videos while you're writing your music?

Do the visuals influence the songwriting process? Or are the visuals planned/done after the song is essentially written?

well, think of it this way, .... there would be no visuals planned BETWEEN the time of song writing and the time of song recording. after the song recording, that is when the visuals happen. but some things were probably obvious during the songwriting process. (i.e. 'lemon song' probably should have a lemon in the video). But here's a new twist that i've found: if you try to come up with visuals at the same time as writing the song, it actually helps you write the song. Even if that visual is not even used.... even if you dont even come up with any specific visual ...... just telling yourself to activate the part of your brain that thinks of visuals, for some reason it makes the songwriting 10x more potent. even if no visual is thought of, it tricks your brain into going to the right place. just to pretend you are supposed to be coming up with the visual. so in other words, when you're writing a song, pretend you're writing a video. it doesn't even matter if you even make a video, just tell your brain you're writing a video, and often you won't even come up with any visual but it still jumpstarts the songwriting when you think that way. hopefully i've explained it. i started doing that with 'best friends with my own front door', and i've been using that trick ever since. it's like opening the door to the next room, to help give you perspective on the room you are in

Was it randomly chosen, or do you have a reason for doing it now?

the selection process was marred with highly potent self-doubting agony, which is to be expected. i did the standard procedure of combing the entire list and selecting ones that seemed like the right choice. then i did a few rounds of writing on those finalists, to boost their status even further. i was expecting to have to randomize amongst those, but i ended up setting a deadline/timelimit on when i had to choose, and just chose. i knew it was the right choice, and yet, the following morning, i reached such high levels of doubt that i actually convinced myself that i CANNOT do that one, and then quickly reminded myself that if i don't stick with that selection then the entire validity of the selection system is broken, and i also had to remind myself that any selection is going to give me various flashes of misery, until i delve into the writing process. i was able to recall that this exact same thing happened with the 'la de da' selection, where i doubted it so badly the next day that i actually changed my mind and then hated that option too and so i had to switch back. basically it all gets better once you start writing on it and start to find solutions for its problems

for notes, you'll want whichever one will allow you to use a unique letter that's different from the notes immediately above and below. so in other words if there is already another type of E above or below, use D#. and if there is already another type of D above or below, use Eb. What does the bottom part of a time signature even mean? I've watched so many videos on it and I still can't grasp its purpose

that is supposed to be what note a beat is. so if the bottom number is 4, the 'quarter' note is supposed to be the beat. if the bottom note is 8, then the 8th note is supposed to be a beat. so "4/4" is supposed to mean there is 4 beats per bar, and a quarter note is 1 beat. "6/2" would mean there is 6 beats in a bar and the half note is one beat. There are some problems with this system-- one problem is that in some countries the notes are not named like this (quarter, eigth, etc). And the other problem is that when the top number is a multiple of 3 and the bottom note is 8, it's usually not actually the 8th note that gets one beat, it's usually actually 3 eighth notes that get one beat. but at least the bar length will adhere correctly to the number system, so for example what i'm trying to say is, 6/8 in the real world usually does not actually mean 6 beats per bar with the 8th note getting one beat. instead it usually actually means there's 2 beats per bar and the dotted quarter note gets one beat. this is mathematically equivalent, but felt differently, for speed. but let's face it, who really wants to write 2/2.667

What should I do if I feel like my song goes on for too long but I like every individual part of the song?

find the 'split point.' run the song from the beginning and find the first part that really doesn't seem good enough. just before that part, this is the 'split point.' take away everything after that (save it, put it on a shelf, don't promise to use it for this). keep running it from the beginning up to the split point and try to figure out what comes next, with no bias toward what you've shelved. although if the shelved contents screams out to you as the perfect thing for the moment immediately after the split point, then you can use it. but always respect the play through from the beginning, and know the split point

HELP! I have a song with a strong sixteenth note rhythm in 4/4 at 130BPM. But halfway through, the sixteenth notes stay the same tempo and switch to a triplet rhythm (alternating 1+ 2+ 3+ 4+ and 1 a2 a3 a4 a). How should I write that? Constant triplet brackets in 4/4? 12/16 time signature? A very uncomfortable 6/8?

your description of the change is not entirely clear, but if it's all groups of 3, i would say use 12/8. and if the value of time needs to change, use 'note equals note' notation. for example if you're using 12/8 and you need the new tempo to be dotted quarter = 130, then write quarter note = dotted quarter note, when the transition occurs. However, (and this was unclear to me from your description) if the old 16th note needs to become the new 8th note (in 12/8) then you can write sixteenth note equals eighth note. Or if you use 12/16 you don't need any conversion. it will also be assumed that it's grouped in 3s if you beam them that way

here are my thoughts about it. it is an interesting case study in deadlines vs non deadlines, it's also an interesting case study in brute force randomized song selection, and it's also a good case study in making arrangement adjustments at the very last moment.
deadlines vs non deadlines:
i knew the entire time when i was making history of the world that i wanted to do songs constantly, forever, and i wanted to do this before history of the world, but history of the world became unexpectedly more important. so the entire time i had the idea that i was going to do songs next. so finally when i was done, i immediately jumped into the song. i had a general idea that i was going to use a weekly deadline, but i wasn't ready to do it quite yet. i wanted to take my time and do it 'right'. i got some good things, the initial groove/vamp sound was found then, and some other things, but after several days, maybe even a week, i felt everything slowing down, and i couldn't seem to make good decisions anymore. so i suddenly set a deadline and then demanded to do them weekly after that. Immediately after setting that deadline, i suddenly made a bunch of bold instrumental choices that wouldn't have been made otherwise. some of the percussion fills in the first verse, a lone loud bongo bonk, a hyper spaz hi-hat fill followed by a huge crash, if i remember correctly those are examples of decisions i made immediately after declaring being on a deadline.
brute force randomized selection:
usually if i try to select the next song without randomized assistance (like, actually choose which one i want to do) it's usually a downward spiral into rejecting everything. every song is too this or too that. too weak, too intense, too emotional, to dumb, too smart, too slow, too fast, too weird, too normal, etc etc. And i have no courage to take any risks. So the alternative to this is just getting a brute force random number. count all the songs in the list, (at this time it was something like 400), and get a computer generated random number from that range, and you MUST do that song. Well, i was willing to accept the result, but the problem here with the result (california) is that the song features a massive marijuana reference. This would be ok except for the fact that i had already had multiple marijuana references in songs before that. Ultimately i went forward with the selection because i felt like i had no other choice, but this highlights a problem with brute force random selection. Yes, it helps you avoid thinking EVERY song is 'wrong', but there's a weird fine line to reckon with because some songs ACTUALLY are 'wrong', considering the previous songs. For example, this song being about california, the following song (also chosen with brute force random) was called "i love you". Well, there is also a song in the list called "California Love" which has nothing to do with those other two. So, imagine for a moment, if "California Love" was picked next, after those other two. that would be terrible, it would look like an obvious deliberate themed connection, which it is not. fortunately the randomizer did not pick that, and the next 2 choices turned out ok. and since then i have developed a hybrid system that allows me to mostly rule out any of these problems before the randomized selection is made
making arrangement changes at the last moment:
usually, after the instrumental arrangement is done, and the vocals are done, and mixing is done, and i'm in the final troubleshooting stage, there can be an extreme resistence against going back and changing things in the arrangement. you just don't want to re-open what seems like a sealed box. but occasionally it has to be done, and i've learned that i MUST let myself be open to that. this song is a good example: those synth riffs in the background of the "it's alright" parts. Those were added at the very end. like during the final adjustments / mixing / troubleshooting phase. i opened the arrangement again to add those riffs there. and it made a huge difference
some additional thoughts about the writing:
it's important to point out that this song was essentially written in august 2011 (about 6 years before it was recorded). So this may slightly change the way the lyrics are perceived. Marijuana was not fully legal in any state at that time. and the reason it is about California is because that is the state that was most well known for marijuana usage at the time, because i think it had recently become legal medically. For every other state mentioned in the song, i'm pretty sure, it was still very illegal, especially in Alabama which i believe had some of the toughest marijuana laws at the time. One of the reasons i featured it in the second verse. Also, the final line of the song (love who you want to) was certainly a reference to the legalization of gay marriage, which at the time was only legal in certain places, which is another thing California was known for at the time
